So some of the things you want to look at is the pros and cons when it comes to the types of rendering. There's forward rendering. But unfortunately, you would have some limitations on the type of light that you would use, which would make things a little bit trickier. The overhead or the idea behind it was so that things could be a little bit lighter. So you weren't using the full capacity of all the things in the engine, but you using just enough to be able to create a nice, efficient VR scenario. There's also deferred rendering. So deferred rendering is the old school way in which Unreal would bake your lighting. It would be fast is especially in small medium scenes and had lower realism compared to ray tracing and lumen. And it's largely a 2D operation calculates lighting with a proxy approximations is complex to use. Now, you'll notice in the first one forward, it says a number of features are not yet supported. So looking at ray tracing and lumen, this is suited for complex effects, GI reflection, refraction and soft shadows. Now refraction is limited, you won't get the same as you would with ray tracing, you'll have to fake some of it, but there will be some ability that you have in here to simulate some of those options. But again, full caustics and refraction you're going to get from path tracer. It's easy to implement when it comes to ray tracing and lumen. It's more intuitive, reliable, realistic and mimics lights behavior. Only lumen is optimized though, keep in mind to be able to be used with ICV effects. Ray tracing leans more towards final pixel. That's because it takes a pretty big hit on your GPU. Now path tracing is not suited for real time. It is not real time or at least the idea of real time was not in mind when it was created. It's for rendering final pixel projects displays a more accurate light refraction and caustic effect takes longer to render than ray tracing or lumen due to sample settings used for better quality and renders each frame independently. It isn't like previous renders such as ray tracing and lumen, or if you rendered it in the movie render queue, it typically will reference the previous frame to be able to make the new one. This one can be used in your typical game scenario, if you need and can be used for virtual production if needed. Ray tracing also can be used for virtual production, but is mainly its focus is on final pixel, such as with movies and so forth. Now we do have some of our ray tracing clients, such as automotive and architecture that will use ray tracing quite often. But again, a lot of the times it's not necessarily for interaction, although it can be used for interaction, you just have to optimize your materials and your items in your scene accordingly. So you get the best frame rate that you possibly can. Lumen is one of the more efficient ways to be able to work and is now unreal out of the box. The GPU renders draw calls by draw call, not triangle by triangle. So in other words, each mesh material is a different draw call. So as you see here down below on this example, you'll see that this sky dome is a draw call. This piece of geo here is a draw call, the floor is a draw call. This other piece of geo, number four, is a draw call and number five. But as soon as you introduce a new material, that becomes a new draw call. So materials and the geometry are to be considered.
